docs.lead_paragraph: At first, it felt like a snow day in June. But one week into a strike that has thrown 10,500 students out of class and 228 teachers behind bars, frustration is turning to anger in this New Jersey town, which not long ago gained international attention as having one of the largest Sept. 11 death tolls.

headline.main: Anger Grows in Middletown Over Teachers' Strike

docs.abstract: Middletown, NJ, teachers strike is seen as one of most bitter and disruptive local labor battles in recent years; mass jailing of teachers is first in country since 1978 and acrimony toward pickets runs high; barbs and death threats fly as parents become increasingly infuriated with situation; photo (M)

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS and ROBERT HANLEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Many of the older workers at the Ford Motor Company plant remember 1982, when a poor economy and flagging demand for the Escort model assembled here led to a cutback to one daily shift, from two. So Monday, when veteran workers heard the surprising news that the same kind of cut, with the loss of 600 jobs, was planned for February, they reacted first with shock and indignation and then with sober and pointed questions about how long the cutbacks would last, the role of seniority and what benefits they would keep.

headline.main: News of Ford Cutback Surprises Edison, Both Plant and Town

docs.abstract: Reaction in Edison, NJ, to Ford's announcement that it will cut 600 jobs discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I gave birth to one child in England and three more in the United States. And when friends ask me about my overseas birthing experience, I tell them I was lucky to be in London the first time around. I am not referring to medical expertise. I am talking about attitudes toward pregnancy and the much-needed help mothers get after their babies are born.

headline.main: So Lucky To Give Birth In England

docs.abstract: Randi Hutter Epstein article compares her experiences giving birth in England and United States (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cindy Brody, my sister-in-law, was only 40 when she realized that something bad was happening to her ability to hear. Telephone conversations were a challenge and there were lots of misunderstandings even during one-on-one conversations, including those with her husband at the dinner table. But the day of reckoning came when she heard a riding instructor say ''to hell with her'' about a disabled woman who wanted to ride a horse, when in fact the man had said ''I'm helping her.''
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dealing with hearing loss, one of most prevalent chronic health conditions in United States; notes some 20 million people with serious hearing deficits fail to use hearing aids; quiz to help in recognizing hearing loss (M)d
